Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Neural Plasticity Driven by Electrical Stimulation of the Retina

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1353018
Weiland

In this EAGER proposal, they will conduct initial experiments to study neural plasticity in both blind humans with retinal implants and in animal models of retinal degeneration. They expect that these initial experiments will establish the experimental techniques and data analysis methods needed to conduct important, ground-breaking studies on the basic neuroscience underlying sight restoration. The objectives are: 1: Assess cortical representations of electrical retinal stimulations delivered via the Argus II retinal prosthesis; 2: Assess cortical plasticity associated with retinal prosthesis use; and 3: Measure neural plasticity in an animal model of retinal degeneration using chronic stimulation.

Successful completion of these objectives will demonstrate feasibility of a set of core techniques that are foundational and transformative for advancing the development of retinal prostheses and the understanding of cortical plasticity in implant recipients.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We completed two major studies on this project. The first study involved comparing the visual cortex response of blind and normal test subjects during tactile activity. Prior brain imaging studies show that the visual cortex of visually impaired humans is active during tactile tasks. We showed that tactile activity, such as counting raised Braille dots or feeling sand paper, reliably evoked activity in the visual cortex and that this activity depends on the extent of blindness. We propose that such cross-modal responses in the parts of the brain that process vision may be used as a cortically localized biomarker to account for individual differences in visual performance following sight recovery treatments. The second study involved analysis of these same brain responses, but in two patients with Argus II retinal implants. When compared to the results of the first study, one Argus II subject who had been implanted for the shorter period of time (6 weeks) exhibited brain responses similar to RP subjects with only minimal light perception. The Argus II subject who had been implanted the longest (15 weeks) had brain responses similar to sighted subjects. Results from these two Argus II subjects indicate that long-term use of a retinal prosthesis may result in a reduction of tactile-evoked responses in visual parts of the brain. Our study also demonstrates that successful acquisition of structural and functional brain images is feasible in the presence of the electronic implant. Such brain imaging studies can potentially provide fundamental insights into human visual neuroscience as well as improve outcomes for patients with retinal implants.
